info.title: Prime Trust API
info.description:
Please read our [Terms of Service](https://primetrust.com/tos) and [Privacy policy](https://primetrust.com/privacy).

Prime Trust's Account Access APIs allows authorized individuals to automate various tasks related to Prime Trust accounts of various types. This means being able to initiate contributions and disbursements, or organize and verify the identity of contacts that will be interacting with accounts.

## Overview
When making basic CRUD-style requests, endpoints usually conform to basic REST principles. For instance, when working with `contacts` the following endpoints are used:

```
GET    /v2/contacts     # Shows all accessible contacts
POST   /v2/contacts     # Creates a new contact
GET    /v2/contacts/:id # Shows a contact
PATCH  /v2/contacts/:id # Updates a contact
DELETE /v2/contacts/:id # Archives a contact
```

Most endpoints support most or all of these calls. Note specifically that `PATCH` is used and not `PUT` for updates (`PUT` is not supported at all). Very little data in the system is ever actually destroyed, so `DELETE` calls are almost always used to take a particular resource out of commission, whether that means archiving a contact so it's no longer part of index views or cancelling a disbursement request, it tends to render a particular object as "no longer usable" rather than actually destroyed.

Additionally, there are certain special actions in the API that don't map very well to a REST pattern. They usually come in the form of a `POST` call to a nested endpoint that operates more like an RPC (Remote Procedure Call). An example of this would be updating the password for a user:

```
POST /v2/users/current/password
```

This is used to create a new password for a user. However, there is no related `GET` request and the resource that is returned will be a user. Some of these endpoints may create a new resource from an existing resource and others will modify an existing resource. Aside from looking at the `id` returned from the endpoint, special actions that create a new resource will return a `201` and those that update a resource will return a `200`.

# Getting Started
Sandbox requests should use `sandbox.primetrust.com` whereas production requests should use `api.primetrust.com`. This document uses paths relative to those hosts.

If you are using one of the Product APIs see the getting started section as well for that set of APIs for more specific information on opening and approving accounts.

A setup at a high level will go as follows:
1. Create a user.
2. Create a JWT with your user.
3. Interact with the authenticated APIs.

## Standard Responses
API responses will always return only one status code. While the JSONAPI spec does have examples of mixed errors, our API does not use them.

* 200: No errors.
* 201: No errors, created. (Used for special actions)
* 202: No errors, accepted but no current response. A `Location` header will tell you where the resource can be found when your request completes processing.
* 204: No errors, no data to return. Common on `DELETE` requests.
* 400: Request malformed, usually from a bad query string or form parameter.
* 401: Not authenticated.
* 403: Forbidden (you're authenticated but lack permission).
* 404: Not found. The API route doesn't exist.
* 405: Method not allowed. The method is not allowed on this API route.
* 422: JSON body didn't validate properly. This error should always be returned related to JSON attributes and not to query string or form parameters except where specifically noted.
* 500: Internal server error.

## Endpoints
Endpoints are organized by resource types and most resource IDs are UUIDs, although there are a few occasions where natural string keys are used for enum-like resources (e.g. `account-types`). So, `contacts` can be found at `/v2/contacts` and a single contact can be found at `/v2/contacts/:id`. If `related` links are not specifically provided in relationships, the location of related resources can be inferred accordingly.

## Index Requests
In addition to the `include`, which all endpoints that return a payload support, index requests can also be paginated, sorted and filtered.

### Includes

Allows for the inclusion of other related resources on the same API call with the keyword `include`. For example:

```
GET v2/contacts?include=cip-check
```

### Pagination
The parameter `page` is used for pagination. `page[number]` indicates the page number and `page[size]` is the maximum number or resources returned. These default respectively to `1` and `25`.

All applicable links are provided in `links`: `first`, `last`, `next`, and `prev`.

Additionally, `meta` properties are returned to indicate totals. `page-count` is the total number of pages and `resource-count` is the total number of resources.

For example, to get the 4th page and show 50 resources per page, you would append the following parameters to your URL:

`?page[number]=4&page[size]=50`

### Sorting
The parameter `sort` is used for sorting how resources are returned. The value should be a comma-separated list of attribute names.

Resources can be sorted both by their own attributes or on the attributes of their respective relationships using a dot (`.`) to separate the relationship name and the attributes. A minus (`-`) is used for sorting in descending order.

For example, if you wanted to sort a contact by their primary street address and then name in descending order you would use the following:

`?sort=primary-address.street-1,-name`

Note specifically that you do not prefix attribute names on the current resource and you use the relationship name, not the resource type, for sorting relationships (e.g `primary-address` is used, not `addresses` which is the resource type of the `primary-address` relationship). Nested sorts are only available for resources immediately related to the current resource. You cannot, for instance, sort with an attribute like: `account.owner.primary-address.country`.

### Filtering - Querying

Filtering can be applied on `GET` calls for certain endpoints so you receive back only the information you require in the response body.

**Filtering Rules**

**Note**: It's important to note that you can't filter by every column.  Right now if you try to filter or sort by something that isn't allowed, the filter or sort is silently ignored or, in the case of bad data (like a number for a date field) you'll get a 500. 
 ,
**Columns on which filtering is allowed**:

Attributes on which **filter** is mentioned are columns you can apply filtering by.

**Operators**
The current operators you can filter by:

Here are the current operators.
* `eq`: Equals (exact match). Used when no operator is specified.
* `gt`: Greater than.
* `gte`: Greater than or equal to.
* `in`: Any item is an exact match. Takes special syntax, so if you wanted something where a status was one of a few, you would pass ?filter[status in]=pending,processing.\
* `like`: Case insensitive search. Does NOT support wildcards as of right now.
* `lt`: Less than.
* `lte`: Less than or equal to.
* `neq`: NOT equal.
* `nin`: NOT in.
* `nlike`: NOT like.
* `sw`: Starts with. Look for strings that being with filter value. Case insensitive.

**Examples of Filtering**

You pass a filter parameter that is the name of a field, potentially namespaced by a relationship, and optional operator (defaults to eq if none are given)

So, to filter contacts by names starting with j:
```
GET /v2/contacts?filter[name sw]=j
```

Filter contacts by account ID:
```
GET /v2/contacts?filter[account.id]=<account uuid>
```

Filter contacts by primary address in Nevada:
```
GET /v2/contacts?filter[primary-address.region]=NV
```

There's also a special shorthand for filtering by id to make related links shorter. Contacts, again, by account ID:
```
GET /v2/contacts?account.id=<account uuid>
```

## Idempotent Object Creation

All `POST` API requests are checked for the presence of a `X-Idempotent-ID` header. The `X-Idempotent-ID` should contain a valid UUIDv4.

If the header exists but does not contain a valid UUIDv4, a `400` error is returned. If the header exists and contains a valid UUIDv4, one of two things can happen:

1. If this `X-Idempotent-ID` has already been used to successfully create/manipulate a resource in the past, then a `202` is returned with a `Content-Location` header that points to the resource.
2. If this X-Idempotent-ID has not already been used, then the API request is processed normally.

**Note**: In both cases there will be a `X-Idempotent-ID` header in the response which exactly matches the `X-Idempotent-ID` header in the request.

**Example Header**

```
X-Idempotent-Id: 1cc2f3fe-e3aa-48d6-966b-9b8a61030dd0
```

### Idempotent Object Creation V2

Idempotent requests have been improved to provide the original status code and
response of a request regardless of outcome.

As with the first version of idempotency, When using the X-Idempotent-ID-V2 header
the requested operation will only ever be executed on our system once as long as
you send us the same UUID value on subsequent requests as you did on the first
request.

However, V2 has the additional property that you will receive back the original
response status code and response body every time you make the request. As soon
as a response has been executed once, it will be returned to you on every
subsequent request made with the same X-Idempotent-ID-V2 header value.

**Example Header**

```
X-Idempotent-ID-V2: 1cc2f3fe-e3aa-48d6-966b-9b8a61030dd0
```

![Sequence diagram of a long running request using X-Idempotent-ID-V2](https://primetrust-eng-public.s3.amazonaws.com/docs/long+request.png)

tags.name: Access Policies
tags.description: Access policies indicate the level of access that a user has to an [account](#tag/Accounts) and/or [funds-transfer-method](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods). If you have full-control to an account you can grant others access via [User Invitations](#tag/User-Invitations) or remove access, for your user or other users, to the resource by deleting the relevant access policy.

tags.name: Account Aggregate Policies
tags.description: Account aggregate policies is a complete aggregation of [account policies](#tag/Account-Policies) that apply to a specific account. It aggregates all policies set on an account no matter the level (global, account-type, organizational, specific account) at which the policy has been set.

tags.name: Account Asset Totals
tags.description:
Account asset totals provides the asset balances for an account. The asset totals in an account are split based on the asset in which the balance is held. The account totals are also split based on the availability of the assets in an account.

* `Settled` is the grand total of assets currently contained in an account. 
* `Contingent-hold` is the current amount of assets in an account that have some hold placed on them that prevent them from being transferred out of an account.
* `Pending-transfer` is the current amount of assets in an account that are contained in a pending transfer out of an account.
* `Disbursable` is the current available amount of assets in an account that can be transferred out the account.

tags.name: Account Cash Totals
tags.description:
Account cash totals provides the cash balances for an account. The cash totals in an account are split based on the currency type in which the balance is held. The account cash totals are also split based on the availability of cash in an account.

* `Settled` is the grand total of cash currently contained in an account. 
* `Contingent-hold` is the current amount of cash in an account that have some hold placed on them that prevent them from being transferred out of an account.
* `Pending-transfer` is the current amount of cash in an account that are contained in a pending transfer out of an account.
* `Disbursable` is the current available amount of cash in an account that can be transferred out the account.

tags.name: Transferring Funds
Depositing Funds
Withdrawing Funds
Account Cash Transfer Reviews
tags.description:
Acccount cash transfer reviews are generated based on the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policies) associated with the account. 

If admin approval and dual-approval is required then two review objects will be generated, one that can be approved by the specified dual approval user and another that can be approved by a Prime Trust administrator. Reviews are only generated on [account-cash-transfers](#tag/Account-Cash-Transfers) that are sending cash out of an account.

The `status`es on internal asset transfer reviews are as follows:

* `pending` is the review is still pending and is awaiting review.
* `approved` is the review has been approved.
* `denied` is the review has been rejected and the associated `account-cash-transfer` will not settle.

tags.name: Account Cash Transfers
tags.description:
Account cash transfers allow the transfer of cash from one Prime Trust account to another Prime Trust account. To be able to transfer from one account to another the user must either have access to both accounts or must be authorized, via [account transfer authorizations](#tag/Account-Transfer-Authorizations), by the receiving account to be able to deposit into it.

Based on the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policies) the `account-cash-transfer` will `settle` instantly or require review.

The statuses which an `account-cash-transfer` can take are as follows.

* `pending` is the cash still needs to leave the sending account.
* `cancelled` is the `account-cash-transfer` has been cancelled, only `pending` `account-cash-transfers` can be cancelled.
* `settled` the `account-cash-transfer` has settled indicating the cash have left the sending account and are in the receiving account now.

tags.name: Sandbox
tags.description: List of routes that allow developers to take actions in the sandbox environment that in the production environment would require a Prime Trust officer to take.

tags.name: Account Policies
tags.description:
Account policies encompass the settings, rules and variables that apply to an account. Though these can be viewed and set at an account level it will be more common for the account-policy for a specific account to be set by the system default or the related umbrella organization. 

There are four possible policies that could apply to an account and each attribute in the account policy will resolve (i.e. be set) in the following order:

1. A policy attached to the account itself. Policies placed directly on an account always take precedent over any other policies.
2. A policy attached to the account's umbrella organization.
3. A policy attached to the account's `account-type`.
4. The global default.

Given that the policies resolve in the above order, for an individual account policy it will be common to see `null` values as these values will have been set at a lower level. This allows specific, single attribute changes to an account policy without having to copy the values from policies further back in the chain. To see the full policy applied to an account view the [account's aggregate policy](#tag/Account-Aggregate-Policies).

tags.name: Account Questionnaires
tags.description: Account questionnaires are a set of compliance questions that may be required to open an account. They contain questions based around transaction activity and purpose of a particular account.

tags.name: Account Transfer Authorizations
tags.description: Account transfer authorizations allow for the transfer of cash or assets between Prime Trust accounts controlled by different users. The receiving account must authorize the sending account using the sending account's account name and account number. This creates a unidirectional (i.e. one directional) linkage between the two accounts allowing the sending account to deposit to the receiving account.

tags.name: Account Types
tags.description: Account types list the various types of accounts that are possible in the Prime Trust API. Some of these accounts can be directly created via the Prime Trust API such as custodial accounts, traditional IRA accounts, and college savings trusts. Other account-types, such as escrow accounts, though they can be interacted with via the API they must be created via by a Prime Trust administrator. These routes will also indicate for a particular account-type which contact based on their `account-role` will be treated as the owner of the account for all intents and purposes and which `account-role` will receive statements and tax-forms.

tags.name: Accounts
tags.description:
Accounts are a "bucket" of cash and assets with a specific legal-wrapper (`account-type`) around them which dictate what actions are permissible on them via the `account-policy` and their legal `agreement`. Most other resources in the Prime Trust API are linked to an account, with the notable exception being [funds-transfer-methods](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods). 

Accounts have a `status` based on where the account is in the account review process at Prime Trust:

* `incomplete` is the account has been created, and will generally shortly move to the `pending` status.
* `pending` is the account is currently pending review. Assets or cash can be deposited to an account at this point in time but are not transferable or disbursable until the account is `opened`.
* `opened` is the account has been opened and is operating.
* `closed` is the account has been closed and is no longer valid except for historical purposes. The account will reach this status if the review is denied or if an account has been opened and was then closed for certain compliance based reasons. If this is the case these reasons will be communicated to outside of the API.

tags.name: Addresses
tags.description: Addresses contain address information and are associated with other resources in the Prime Trust API such as `contacts` or `funds-transfer-methods`.

tags.name: Agreement Previews
tags.description: Agreement previews allow the generation of filled out previews with the potential account owner's information that are based on the agreement template set for the organization and account type. These are needed to show the account agreement to the potential account owner before they agree to open a Prime Trust account.

tags.name: Agreements
tags.description: Agreements are generated for an account after creation. A counter signed version of the agreement is available after the account has been opened.

tags.name: Prime Trust's KYC Process
Asset Contributions
tags.description:
Asset contributions represent exepcted incoming asset deposits (digital or traditional assets deposits). When created they also create an incoming [asset-transfer](#tag/Asset-Transfers) which can then be used to track the lifecycle of the particular deposit.

When created an  `incoming` [asset-transfer-method](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods) can be specified or a new `single-use` `true` `asset-transfer-method` will be created specifically for the asset-contribution and will be marked `inactive` after assets are received for the `asset-contribution`. See [asset-transaction-tax-lots](#tag/Asset-Transaction-Tax-Lots) for more information on `cost-basis` and `acquitision-date`.

tags.name: Depositing Assets
Asset Disbursements
tags.description:
Asset disbursements represet a request to send assets out of an account to a specified external location.  When created they also create an outgoing [asset-transfer](#tag/Asset-Transfers) which can then be used to track the lifecycle of the particular withdrawal.
 
Asset disbursements must be linked via in-line creation of an `outgoing` [asset-transfer-method](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods) or to a pre-existing `outgoing` [asset-transfer-method](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods).

tags.name: Withdrawing Assets
Asset Transaction Tax Lots
tags.description:
Asset transaction tax lots are created or added to based on the tax information (`cost-basis` and `acquisition-date`) specified on incoming asset-transfers which are taken from the appropriate `incoming` [asset-transfer-method](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods). As the name suggests tax lots are used to track taxes on a particular account.

By default the Prime Trust API follows a FIFO (first in first out) methodology of tracking tax lots so a transfer out of assets will begin by depleting the tax-lot with the earliest `acquisition-date`.

* `Cost-basis` is the price per unit at which the asset was acquired.
* `Acquisition-date` is the date at which the assets were the acquired at the specified `cost-basis`.

tags.name: Transferring Assets
Asset Transactions
tags.description: Asset transactions represent the transactional ledger of assets for a particular account. They are created when assets are `settled` into or out of an account. An `asset-transaction` is ideally never removed once created.

tags.name: Asset Transfer Methods
tags.description: Asset transfer methods provide instructions on where assets will be received or where Prime Trust should send outgoing assets. They are also linked to a particular `account` (generally a `contact` as well) and particular tax-lot information. Any assets received to an asset-transfer-method will be booked to Prime Trust's APIs with that asset-transfer-method's tax-lot information.

tags.name: Asset Transfers
tags.description:
Asset transfers represent the lifecycle of incoming or outgoing assets from an account external of the Prime Trust ecosystem. They are always linked to an `asset-contribution` or `asset-disbursement`. They can be incoming or outgoing depending on the sign of the `amount` attribute. They are never created directly via the API but are created based on other resource creation or based on certain events taking place.

**Incoming Asset Transfers**

Incoming asset transfers are created either when [asset-contributions](#tag/Asset-Contributions) are created or when assets are received to an existing active multi-use [asset-transfer-method](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods) in the case of digital assets (this also creates a corresponding `asset-contribution`).

Assets related to an incoming asset-transfer are only usable once any [contingent-holds](#tag/Contingent-Holds) related to the asset are cleared. At this point in time the `contingincies-cleared-at` field will receive a value. Note that incoming asset-transfers will `settle` before this field receives a value.

**Outgoing Asset Transfers**

Outgoing asset transfers are created when an [asset-disbrusement](#tag/Asset-Disbursements) are created.

Assets related to an outgoing asset-transfer are only `settled` once all `contingent-holds` and [disbursement-authorizations](#tag/Disbursement-Authorizations) related to the outgoing asset-transfer are cleared.

Asset transfers have certain `status`es which help track the incoming or outgoing asset-transfer. 

* `pending` is the transfer has been created but Prime Trust is still waiting to fully receive the assets or Prime Trust still needs to send the assets out.
* `cancelled` is the transfer has been cancelled, this can only be done when the `asset-transfer` is still `pending`.
* `settled` the assets have been received by Prime Trust or the assets have been delivered out of Prime Trust.

tags.name: Assets
tags.description:
Assets are representations of all the underlying assets Prime Trust can custody. They indicate what type of asset it is and how the ownership of the asset is tracked. Incoming [Asset Transfer Methods](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods) can only be generated for assets where `requires-manual-deposit` is set to `false`. If this is set to true then an asset-transfer-mehtod must be requested outside of the API. 

Note that for assets that are on the ethereum blockchain Prime Trust in non production environments Prime Trust uses the Ropsten test net.

tags.name: Account Transaction Policies
Banks
tags.description: Banks provides a list of domestic (US) bank information for convenience including routing number and address. A bank is linked to a `wire` or `ach` `funds-transfer-type` [funds transfer method](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Method).

tags.name: Credit Card Integration
Embeddables Integration
Card Holder Verifications
tags.description:
This resource is used as a part of the Prime Issuance white label debit card issuance process. The resource manages the card holder verification process and provisions virtual cards at the completion of the verification process. Use this resource to verify the email and phone number of the card holder associated with the issued card. Once verified, the system issues a virtual card for the card holder. See [Card Issuance](#tag/Card-Issuance) for more information about the Prime Issuance process.

Please contact your account representative to enable these routes.

tags.name: Card Holders
tags.description:
`Card holder` objects associate existing Prime Trust `account` and `contact` objects with the person to whom a Prime Issuance debit card is issued. A card holder must already have a verified Prime Trust custodial account. See [Card Issuance](#tag/Card-Issuance) for more information about the Prime Issuance process.

Please contact your account representative to enable these routes.

tags.name: Card Issuance
tags.description:
Card Issuance is currently in invite-only private Beta.

Please see the [Debit Card Issuance Guide](https://developers.primetrust.com/docs/card-issuance) for integration steps.

tags.name: Card Transactions
tags.description:
Use this resource to retrieve Prime Issuance card transactions and to run test transactions in the sandbox environment.  See [Card Issuance](#tag/Card-Issuance) for more information about the Prime Issuance process.

Please contact your account representative to enable these routes.

tags.name: Cards
tags.description:
`Card` objects represent white label debit cards issued by Prime Trust. `Card` objects store information about the card holder, issuance date, card status, and if a physical card was issued for the card holder (cards are virtual by default). Before cards can be issued, card holders must be created and verified. The `cards` resource enables you to retrieve, lock, unlock, and reissue cards. See [Card Issuance](#tag/Card-Issuance) for more information about the Prime Issuance process.

Please contact your account representative to enable these routes.

tags.name: Cash Transactions
tags.description: Cash transactions represent the transactional ledger of cash for a specific account. They are craeted when funds are `settled` (moved) into or out of an account. They are also created when a [funds-transfer](#tag/Funds-Transfers) is `reversed` which equates to funds moving back into or out of an account. A `cash-transaction` is ideally never removed once created.

tags.name: Contact Funds Transfer References
tags.description: Contact funds transfer references generate a unique static reference for a particular contact and account. These references begin with a "Q". They are especially useful when receiving wire or check deposits as these codes can be presented to the end-user along with the relevant static wire instructions or check mailing instructions. A deposit then received with this reference code on it will be booked to the appropriate account and hence there is no need to create a contribution ahead of time for these types of deposits.

tags.name: Contact Relationships
tags.description:
Contact relationships indicate how multiple [contacts](#tag/Contacts) are related together. This is generally used for contacts that are companies as it shows how a company is related to beneificial owners, associated persons and authorized signatories. A company must always have at least one `primary` contact relationship to a natural person and a `primary` contact-relationship cannot be deleted until another natural person is listed as the `primary` contact relationship.

A company contact is `related-to` beneficial owners, beneficial entities and associated persons etc. Vice-versa beneficial owners, beneificial entities and asscociated persons etc. are `related-from` the original company contact.

tags.name: Contacts
tags.description:
Contacts represent the KYC information and KYC status of the end-user and live at an account level. Contacts can also be linked to other resources such as [funds-transfers](#tag/Funds-Transfers), [asset-transfers](#tag/Asset-Transfers), [funds-transfer-methods](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods), and [asset-transfer-methods](#tag/Asset-Transfer-Methods).

Contacts can have one or multiple `account-roles` and should not have any `account-roles` if they are purely being passed in for compliance purposes such as for an omnibus account relationship. Any contact listed with the `account-role` `owner` will receive a disbusement authorization email on an outgoing funds or asset transfer. To add contacts to an account without any roles the appropriate account policy `allow-organizational-contacts` must be set to `true`.

Companies require at least one `related-contact` of type `natural-person` unless the company itself is a `related-contact` of the original company.

When passing in information for a non-US individual then the `tax-id-number` must be filled out with the govt id. number listed on the document uploaded for kyc verification.

There are multiple statuses that relate to the various stages of the KYC process:

1. CIP checks and KYC document checks.
    * `cip-cleared`: Set to `true` when the corresponding [CIP check](#tag/CIP-Checks) for the contact has been approved.
    * `identity-documents-verified`: Set to `true` when a [KYC document check](#tag/KYC-Document-Checks) indicating proof of ID for that contact has been approved.
    * `proof-of-address-documents-verified`: Set to `true` when a KYC document check indicating proof of address for that contact has been approved.
    * `identity-confirmed`: Set to `true` when the above atttributes are all `true`.

2. AML checks
    * `aml-cleared`: Set to `true` when the corresponding [AML check](#tag/AML-Checks) for the contact has been approved.

tags.name: Contingent Holds
tags.description:
Contingent holds are temporary holds placed on incoming or outgoing funds or asset transfers that relate to specific checks or actions needing to complete before the funds or assets can be released/free to use.

An incoming funds or asset transfer is considered to be held if the following are true:

1. The transfer has a status of `settled`.
2. The transfer has one or more `contingent-holds` with a status of `pending`.

An outgoing funds or asset transfer is considered to be held if the following are true:

1. The transfer has a status of `pending`.
2. The transfer has one or more contingent holds with a status of `pending`.

The hold-types possible are listed below and appropriate actions that can be taken:
 
| **Hold Name**                | **Hold Meaning**                                                                                                                                       | **Action**                                                                                                         |
|------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `aml_check`                  | There is a pending aml-check related to this transfer.                                                                                                 | None, wait for the related aml-check to clear                                                                      |
| `contact_kyc_checks`         | The contact linked to this transfer has pending cip-checks and/or aml-checks.                                                                          | Check the contact's cip-check and/or aml-check                                                                     |
| `contact_kyc_documents`      | The contact linked to this transfer still needs to clear kyc-document-checks.                                                                          | Check the contact's kyc-document-check or create a kyc-document-check for the contact with the relevant documents. |
| `disbursement_authorization` | The disbursement authorization linked to the outgoing transfer still needs to reach the authorized state.                                              | None, wait for the disbursement-authorization related to the outgoing funds-transfer to be cleared.                |
| `funds_not_cleared`          | There is hold on the funds that will clear in the future. In general a 10 day hold is placed on incoming ACH funds-transfers after they have settled.  | None, wait for the funds to clear                                                                                  |

tags.name: Contributions
tags.description:
Contributions represent expected incoming cash deposits. When created they also create an incoming [funds-transfer](#tag/Funds-Transfers) which can then be used to track the lifecycle of the particular deposits.

Contributions need to be created on deposits of funds-transfer-types where Prime Trust needs to pull the funds from a particular [funds-transfer-method](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods), such as `funds-transfer-type` of `ach` or `credit_card`. The `funds-transfer-method` can be created in-line on contribution creation or an existing `funds-transfer-method` when creating the contribution.

For incoming deposits of `funds-transfer-type` `wire` or `check` creating a contribution ahead of time is optional. If a contribution is not created ahead of time then a [contact-funds-transfer-reference](#tag/Contact-Funds-Transfer-Reference) must be generated and presented along with the Prime Trust wire instructions. If a contribution is created ahead of time then the `reference` from the contribution should be presented along with rest of the wire instructions to the end-user. 

On contributions note that `wire` is used as the `funds-transfer-type` for incoming domestic (US) and international wires (Non US).

Note do not use the `status` on the `contribution`, this only exists for legacy integrators but instead use the `status` on the `funds-transfer`.

**Multi-Destination Contributions**

Multi-Destination Contributions allow an initial transfer of funds from an external bank account to Prime Trust’s bank account followed by subsequent logical transfers to Prime Trust custodial (or other) accounts. The contribution itself or “parent” should now be specified with the aggregate total of all children. This allows you to easily split an incoming contribution between multiple accounts and allows the seamless processing of fees.

tags.name: Countries
tags.description: Countries provides a list of countries supported by Prime Trust and information on whether those countries are supported for automated cip-checks, aml-checks, and kyc-document-checks.

tags.name: Credit Card Resources
tags.description:
Credit card resources allow generation of tokens for use in Prime Trust's card (debit & credit) authorization secure widget (iFrame). This ensures that sensitive card information does not need to be handled by the integrator.

These endpoints also allow verification of cards when the user returns to the widget with the 4 digit code they retrieve from their bank account.

**Overview of Credit/Debit card authorization process**
1. Create a [contact](#tag/Contacts).
2. Create a `credit-card-resource` and retrieve the `resource-token-hash` for use in the widget.
3. Initialize the widget with the `resource-token-hash`
4. Verify the card with the 4 digit descriptor passed back from the end-user through the widget.
5. Use the verified [funds-transfer-method](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods) to create a [contribution](#tag/Contributions).

**Card Verification process for the end user**
1. Enter Card Information via widget
2. PT places a temporary authorization hold on the card for a certain small random amount with a 4 digit descriptor in the billing descriptor on the transaction.
3. User enters in 4 digit descriptor to verify the card for future charging purposes.

This two factor verification process helps reduce chargeback risk.

The status on a `credit-card-resource` are as follows:

* `pending` is the credit-card-resource has been created.
* `authorized` is the temporary hold with the 4 digit `descriptor` has been placed on the on the card post checking of card information.
* `verified` is the card has been verified with the 4 digit `descriptor` and now can be charged successfully.

tags.name: Currencies
tags.description: Currencies provides a list along with further information of FIAT currencies supported by Prime Trust.

tags.name: Disbursement Authorizations
tags.description:
Disbursement authorizations track the verification and authorization lifecycle of an outgoing asset or funds transfer. After a [disbursement](#tag/Disbursements) or [asset-disbursement](#tag/Asset-Disbursements) has been made, creating an underlying funds or asset transfer, two more stages need to be cleared before the funds or assets leave the account at Prime Trust.

**Stages in Disbursement Authorization**

1. Owner Verification is the outgoing funds or asset transfer needs to be confirmed via an automated email by at least one of the [contacts](#tag/Contacts) on the account with the `account-role` of `owner`. Whether this step is required is based on the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policies).
2. Authorization is after `owner-verification` and requires further approval by a Prime Trust officer. `Disbursement-Authorizations` will automatically become `authorized` if authorization is not required on the account as controlled by the account's `account-policy`. 

Note that a `pending` `disbursement-authorization` will also place a [contingent-hold](#tag/Contingent-Holds) on the respective funds or asset transfer.

There are multiple statuses a `disbursement-authorization` can have as listed below.

* `pending` is the `disbursement-authorization` is waiting for owner verification.
* `owner_verified` is the owner has has verified the disbursement.
* `authorized` is the disbursement has been authorized. The outgoing funds or asset transfer can only be `settled` after the `disbursement-authorization` has reached this stage as it will clear the respective `contingent-hold`.

The `owner-verification-type` can be `email` or `waived_by_owner` if the appropriate `account-policy` has been set to not require owner verification.

tags.name: Disbursements
tags.description:
Disbursements are requests to withdraw cash out of an account at Prime Trust to an external location. A disbursement when created will create an outgoing [funds-transfer](#tag/Funds-Transfer) which can then be used to track the lifecycle of the transfer.

Disbursements unlike contributions must always be linked to a [funds-transfer-method](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods) either to a pre-existing one or to a new one via in-line creation. They can also contain a unique reference provided by the end-user required by certain banks and other providers to receive funds.

Note do not use the `status` on the `disbursement`, this only exists for legacy integrators but instead use the `status` on the `funds-transfer`.

tags.name: Electronic Signatures
tags.description:
Electronic signatures are recoreded when any agreement in the system is signed by the end-user and then when signed by a Prime Trust officer. 

The most common example is when agreements are signed on opening an account, when the account is created the `authorized-signature` is recorded and when the account is `opened` Prime Trust's counter signature is recorded.

tags.name: Funds Transfer Methods
tags.description:
Funds transfer methods are used to collect information for funds/cash transmission to and from accounts.

**Incoming Funds Transfer Methods' Types supported**

Not all incoming [contributions](#tag/Contributions)/[funds-transfers](#tag/Funds-Transfers) require a funds-transfer-method, though the `funds-transfer-type` still needs to specified on the contribution (such as `wire` and `check`). Prime Trust  only needs a funds-transfer-method when we need to pull/retrieve the funds from a specified location/account. The `funds-transfer-method` types that can be used on incoming transfers are as follows:

* `ach` can only be used to pull funds from US bank accounts.
* `credit_card` can be used to charge a credit or debit card, all funds settle in USD.

**Outgoing Funds Transfer Methods' Types supported**

All outgoing [disbursements](#tag/Disbursements)/[funds-transfers](#tag/Funds-Transfers) require a funds-transfer-method since Prime Trust needs to know where the funds need to be sent. The `funds-transfer-method` types that can be used on outgoing transfers are as follows:

* `ach` can only be used to send funds to US bank accounts.
* `check` to send funds via physical check to someone.
* `wire` to send a wire to a US bank account.
* `wire_international` to send a wire outside of the US.

If the [account-policy](#tag/account-policy) for an account requires that a contact be linked on an outgoing `funds-transfer` then the `funds-transfer-method` used on the disbursement must be linked to a contact and the contact must have cleared Prime Trust's KYC process.

tags.name: Plaid ACH Integration
Funds Transfers
tags.description:
Funds transfers track the lifecycle of cash deposits (contributions) and withdrawals (disbursements) from a Prime Trust account. Funds transfers may be associated with one or more cash transactions as well with other funds-transfers. They can be incoming or outgoing depending on the sign of the `amount` attribute. They are never created directly via the API but are created based on other resource creation or based on certain events taking place. Funds transfers are always linked to a [contribution](#tag/Contributions), [disbursement](#tag/Disbursements) or [refund](#tag/Refunds).

**Incoming Funds Transfers**

Incoming `funds-transfers` are created when a `contribution` is created.

Incoming funds are only usable when the associated `funds-transfer` has been cleared of any [contingent holds](#tag/Contingent-Holds). At this point in time the `contingincies-cleared-at` field will receive a value. Note that incoming asset-transfers will `settle` before this field receives a value and the `contingent-holds` are cleared.

**Outgoing Funds Transfers**

Outgoing `funds-transfers` are created when a `disbursement` or `refund` is created.

Outgoing funds-transfers can only be `settled` once all of its associated `contingent-holds` have been cleared.

There are multiple `status`es a funds-transfer can take and they are listed below.

* `pending` is the funds-transfer is pending either funds still need to be received or the the outgoing transfer of funds still needs to be processed.
* `cancelled` is the funds-transfer has been cancelled, only `pending` funds-transfers can be cancelled.
* `settled` is the funds-transfer has been `settled` i.e. funds have been received or funds have left the account at Prime Trust.
* `reversed` is used if there has been a settlement issue with the funds-transfer, generally during the clearing period for the funds-transfer. An example being an ACH failure or credit card chargeback.

tags.name: Internal Asset Transfer Reviews
tags.description:
Internal asset transfer reviews are generated based on the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policies) associated with the account. 

If admin approval and dual-approval is required then two review objects will be generated, one that can be approved by the specified dual approval user and another that can be approved by a Prime Trust administrator. Reviews are only generated on [internal-asset-transfers](#tag/Internal-Asset-Transfers) that are sending assets out of an account.

The `status`es on internal asset transfer reviews are as follows:

* `pending` is the review is still pending and is awaiting review.
* `approved` is the review has been approved.
* `denied` is the review has been rejected and the associated `internal-asset-transfer` will not settle.

tags.name: Internal Asset Transfers
tags.description:
Internal assets transfers allow the transfer of assets from one Prime Trust account to another Prime Trust account. To be able to transfer from one account to another the user must either have access to both accounts or must be authorized, via [account transfer authorizations](#tag/Account-Transfer-Authorizations), by the receiving account to be able to deposit into it.

Based on the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policies) the `internal-assets-transfer` will `settle` instantly or require review.

The statuses which an `internal-assets-transfer` can take are as follows.

* `pending` is the assets still needs to leave the sending account.
* `cancelled` is the `internal-assets-transfer` has been cancelled, only `pending` `internal-assets-transfers` can be cancelled.
* `settled` the `internal-assets-transfer` has settled indicating the assets have left the sending account and are in the receiving account now.

tags.name: Payment Methods
tags.description: Payment methods is a deprecated form of [funds-transfer-methods](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods).

tags.name: Phone Numbers
tags.description: Phone numbers are generally associated with contact and cotain the phone information where the [contact](#tag/Contacts) can be reached.

tags.name: Plaid Items
tags.description: Plaid items lists [funds-transfer-methods](#tag/Funds-Transfer-Methods) that have been authorized or added via [Plaid](). This is for now only used on ACH `funds-transfer-methods`.

tags.name: Quotes
tags.description:
The `quotes` resource is part of the Prime Liquidity product. The `quotes` resource enables you to request, execute, and view quotes for a digital asset purchase or sale. 

Use `POST /v2/quotes/` to request a quote from the Prime Trust trade desk liquidity network. The `account-id` attribute specifies an account to fund the quote. For example, you would specify an account holding USD for a BTC buy request. You can specify the amount in USD or asset units (BTC is currently supported). You can specify either the total amount including fees, or an amount not including fees. You can optionally specify a `trade-desk-id` attribute if you need to override the Prime Trust default providers. The `hot` attribute specifies whether to access hot or cold wallets from the quote provider. Both hot and cold wallet requests return a valid quote, though hot wallets result in immediate access to the asset. The `expires-at` response attribute returns the window for quote requests before the quote expires. Expiration times vary depending upon the trade desk used. Window times can be as short as eight seconds (including the time for processing requests, which takes about three seconds). 

Use `POST /v2/quotes/{quote-id}/execute/` to execute a quote. You'll need to have enough existing funds in the specified `account-id` in order to successfully process the requested quote. Once executed, the system initates the trade and records a ledger entry. All execution failures are atomic and result in a return to the initial states for the requestor and the provider.

Use `GET /v2/quotes/` to return a list of your quotes.

Use `GET /v2/quotes/id/` to return a specified quote.

tags.name: Refunds
tags.description:
Refunds allow the return of incoming [funds-transfers](#tag/Funds-Transfers) back to the contributor of the original funds. A common use case will be the failure to meet a [contingent-hold](#tag/Contingent-Holds) on an incoming funds transfer such as failure to clear Prime Trust's KYC process. Ideally non-retrievable services will not have already been delivered when a refund is requested. A refund could be initiated by a Prime Trust administrator or by the user themselves. 

Note that a refund will only be able to be processed after the funds have settled at Prime Trust and have passed any funds clearing related contingent-holds. This is especially important for refunds on incoming ach `funds-transfers`.

tags.name: Trades
tags.description:
`Trade` objects store transaction information about the trading of assets or cash.

'Trade' objects are generated after a successful quote execution. Once a Quote has been executed a trade will be added to the account's trade records for future reference to the transaction. 

'Trade' objects can also represent instant settlement of assets and cash. Trades can include a broker fee for agency brokers if the broker is enabled on both accounts. 

A trade must have an initiator and an acceptor. Both the initiator and acceptor provide values for `amount` and `currency-type`. Only a user with `full-control` of an account can create or accept a trade. To create a trade between accounts controlled by different users, the initator must have the ability to be listed as authorized transfer accounts.

A trade can take the following statuses:

1. `pending`
2. `settled`
3. `cancelled`

Asset-for-cash trades will create a total of two asset transactions and two cash transactions. 

Asset-for-asset trades will create a total of four asset transactions.

Endpoints:

+ List all trades - `GET /v2/trades`

+ Create a trade - `POST /v2/trades`

+ Retrieve a trade - `GET /v2/trades/{trade-id}`

+ Settle a trade - `POST /v2/trades/{trade-id}/settle` - can only be called by user with full control for the acceptor account

+ Cancel a trade - `POST /v2/trades/{trade-id}/cancel` - can only be called by user with full control for the acceptor account

tags.name: Uploaded Documents
tags.description:
This endpoint allows documents to be uploaded to the PrimeTrust system. This endpoint will generally be used for uploading documents for [kyc-document-checks](#tag/KYC-Document-Checks). Documents can be linked to a contact or to an account for the purpose of KYC documents should always be linked to the [contact](#tag/Contacts).

Unlike other endpoints the POST request does not conform with JSONAPI and instead uses a multipart form request. Only one file can be uploaded per request. And hence a `Header` with `Content-Type: multipart/form-data` must be set.

tags.name: User Invitation Reviews
tags.description:
User invitation reviews allow another user to also have to approve [user-invitations](#tag/User-Invitations) that are created on accounts. The user that has to approve the review is specified in the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policies) on the account.

The `status`es on a `user-invitation-review` is as follows.

* `pending` is the `user-invitation-review` still is in the process of being reviewed.
* `approved` is the `user-invitation-review` has been accepted and the `user-invitation` will be sent out.
* `denied` is the `user-invitation-review` has been rejected and the `user-invitation` will not be sent out.

tags.name: User Invitations
tags.description:
User invitations allow invitation of other user's to an account with varying levels of access. If the user does not exist ahead of time then they will receive an email allowing them to sign up for a user.

The varying levels of access are as follows.

* `full-access` has full-control of the account and can even remove the original user that granted access.
* `manage` can do everything a full-control user can do but cannot invite new users to the account or remove existing users.
* `read-only` has read only access to the account.
* `dual-control` if dual-control [account-policies](#tag/Account-Policies) are configured then this is the user which will be able to approve reviews related to [account-cash-transfers](#tag/Account-Cash-Transfers) and [internal-asset-transfers](#tag/Internal-Asset-Transfers).

tags.name: Users
tags.description:
Users are the starting point for the rest of Prime Trust's APIs. In order to interact with any of the authenticated endpoints, you need to create a user. After creating a user you can create a JWT to authenticate with other end points,see [authentication](#tag/Authentication) for more information. 

Depending on how you're structuring your platform, it might make sense to create an extreme "bot" type user for handling automated API requests or have multiple users that take specific actions to make your integration more secure.

User's can also have certain configurations set on them such as MFA TOTP for JWT creation, set time limits on JWTs created by the user, IP whitelists and claims set on the user to limit the user's access to certain routes. To have these configurations set on a user plese reach out to your sales engineer.

tags.name: Setting Up
Webhook Configs
tags.description:
Webhook configs are set on a per account level and control settings related to webhooks including which URL the webhooks related to that account will be sent to. [Webhooks](#tag/Webhooks) can be verified using the `shared-secret` available on the `webhook-config`. They can be created inline on account opening as well and this is the reccomended configuration mechanism to ensure that no `webhooks` are missed.

`Webhook-configs` are by default disabled if there are 10 total webhook failures. This can be configured on the [account-policy](#tag/Account-Policy) and can be increased to accomodate for more failures. A failure is determined as a non-200 response and hence it is essential to respond with 200 even if a particular webhook is not essential to your use case. Webhooks are retried 300s after a failure.

tags.name: Webhooks
tags.description:
Webhooks present a log of webhooks over the past 60 days that Prime Trust has or would have fired along with failure details if the webhooks fired.

**Webhook Verification**

Each webhook request includes the header `X-Prime-Trust-Webhook-Hmac`, a base64-encoded SHA256 digest. It is generated using the shared secret available in the [webhook-config](#tag/Webhook-Config) along with the exact body of the webhook sent in the webhook request.

To verify the webhook came from Prime Trust compute the HMAC hash and compare it to the value in the `X-Prime-Trust-Webhook-Hmac` header. If they match, you can be sure that the webhook was sent from Prime Trust and the data has not been compromised.

tags.name: Authentication
tags.description: Authentication allows access to all other endpoints in the Prime Trust APIs outside of [users](#tag/Users). To authenticate with all other endpoints a JWT will need to be created using basic auth with the `user-email` and `password`.
